State Key Laboratory of Polyolefins and Catalysis Shanghai 200062 PR China Immobilizing metallocene catalysts on suitable carriers can overcome the drawbacks of their homogeneous counterpart in catalyzing olefin polymerization. However, the development of porous organic carriers with tunable specific surface area, pore structure and commendable compatibility for metallocene catalyst loading remains challenging. In this study, porous organic polymers (POPs) with tunable specific surface area (158–1407 m2/g) and pore volume (0.15–1.04 cm3/g) were successfully fabricated by a facile one-pot method through direct knitting of aromatic copolymer monomers. We provided a comprehensive investigation into the impact of specific surface area, pore structure and chemical structure of POPs on the catalytic polymerization of ethylene as POPs-supported metallocene catalysts. The results reveal that interactions among POPs, MAO and Cp2ZrCl2 govern both the formation and spatial distribution of active sites as well as the overall catalytic activity. The catalytic kinetics show that the POPs-supported metallocene catalysts exhibited no initiation period during ethylene polymerization. And the catalytic activity (20513 kgPE(mol Zr)−1h−1) is reached with a support possessing a specific surface area of 438 m2/g and a pore volume of 0.26 cm3/g. This work highlights the significant potential of POPs as tailor-made porous organic polymer carriers for metallocene-catalyzed ethylene polymerization. Graphical Abstract Keywords Direct knitting Porous organic polymer Metallocene catalyst Ethylene polymerization Tailored pores Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Polyethylene products are utilized extensively in various applications, including packaging, additives and consumer goods, due to their advantageous properties of low cost, stability and wide applicability [1–3]. In recent decades, researchers have made continuous efforts to enhance the productivity and performance control of various ethylene polymerization processes [4–6]. It is well established that the catalyst plays a pivotal role in determining the structure and properties of the polyethylene product [7]. The precise configuration of the catalyst structures facilitates the meticulous regulation of the polymerization process, thereby enabling the synthesis of polyethylene with exceptional properties [8,9]. Metallocene catalysts are considered to be effective catalysts for olefin polymerization [10]. Compared with Ziegler-Natta and Phillips catalysts, they exhibit higher catalytic activity and molecular weights, along with narrower molecular-weight distributions [11]. Metallocene catalysts were initially developed in a homogeneous state [12,13]. While the homogeneous process is of commercial importance, the multiphase (i.e. supported catalyst-based) slurry or vapor-phase process remains the primary method of manufacturing polyethylene. This is attributable to the challenges associated with the intricate control of morphology and the occurrence of reactor contamination in the context of polymerization products from homogeneous catalysts [14,15]. Consequently, the loading of metallocene complexes onto appropriate carriers is imperative. Silica [16–19] remains the predominant commercial support in industrial olefin polymerization, owing to its tunable pore architecture, high specific surface area, and cost-effectiveness. However, silica-based carriers are often limited by broad particle size distributions and poorly controlled surface chemistry, leading to non-uniform active site environments. Critically, the inherent Lewis acidity of the silica surface can poison metallocene catalysts, requiring extensive deactivation treatments prior to use. Additional drawbacks include poor compatibility with polyolefin products and the risk of inorganic residue contamination, which may adversely affect polymer properties [20–22]. In contrast, organic polymer supports provide superior compatibility with polyolefins, tunable surface functionalization, and more homogeneous distribution of active species. These advantages have motivated increased research into functionalized organic and organic–inorganic hybrid supports with tailored porosity and chemical environments. Emerging supports such as metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) and covalent organic frameworks (COFs) have attracted recent attention. MOFs [23] can facilitate unique interactions with metallocene/ MAO catalytic systems, promoting multi-site behavior; however, their practical implementation is hindered by structural instability under reaction conditions, non-innocent metal nodes, propensity for pore blockage, and cumbersome synthesis. COFs [24] offer highly ordered porous frameworks conducive to nanoconfinement effects and precise microenvironment design. Nonetheless, their application often necessitates complex pretreatment procedures such as MAO functionalization, which remains a significant obstacle to their widespread adoption. Conversely, porous organic polymers (POPs) exhibit high performance in applications such as adsorption [25], catalysis [26–30], and energy storage [31,32]. This can be attributed to their tunable specific surface areas, pore volumes, and pore sizes, which can be precisely tailored through versatile synthetic strategies, along with their ease of functionalization. [33–35]. In recent years, research has been undertaken into the use of POPs in Metallocene catalysts [36,37]. POPs have shown a capacity to circumvent the toxicity of inorganic carriers to metallocene catalysts, thereby obviating the necessity for the rigorous pre-treatment of inorganic carriers. A number of studies have revealed the effect of properties such as carrier-specific surface area, porosity and organic linkers on ethylene polymerization, and have successfully prepared polyolefin materials [38,39]. However, the catalytic activity of metallocene catalysts supported on porous organic polymers remains relatively low, and the underlying loading mechanism is not yet well understood. In this work, a method for preparing a range of porous organic polymers (POPs) with different hierarchical pore structures by direct knitting is provided. An investigation was conducted into the effects of reaction solvent, monomer type and amount, cross-linker type and amount, and Lewis acid on the chemical structure, specific surface area, and pore structure of the carriers. A comparison was made of the changes in Cp2ZrCl2 loading in four porous organic polymer carriers with different chemical structures, specific surface areas and pore volumes and sizes to show how the carrier structure affects the generation of active sites and the catalyzed ethylene polymerization reaction. It was found that the specific surface area and the pore volume of the pores could be significantly altered by varying the type and amount of monomers utilized in the copolymerization process. In slurry polymerization systems, metallocene catalysts supported on porous organic polymers (POPs) have been shown to exhibit enhanced catalytic activity compared to conventional supported catalysts. This straightforward approach of directly modifying the carrier's chemical and pore structures enables atomic-level dispersion of metal active centers within a hierarchically porous matrix. This facilitates precise molecular-level design and modulation of the loaded catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 POPs preparation As shown in Fig. 1, phenol (the principal monomer) and aromatic comonomers (benzene, tetraphenylmethane) were charged into a Schlenk flask under an argon (Ar) atmosphere. The reaction solvent was 1,2-dichloroethane (DCE), and the cross-linker was dimethoxymethane (FDA). Following adequate dissolution, the Lewis acid catalyst (FeCl3 / AlCl3) was charged, and the reaction was sealed and maintained at 80 ℃ for 6 h. After cooling to room temperature, the product was filtered and washed sequentially with methanol, water, ethanol, acetone and Dichloromethane (DCM) 2–3 times each. Following drying, a free-flowing brown solid powder was obtained, denoted as POP-OH-X (where X represents the sample sequence number). Detailed experimental conditions are provided in the Supporting Information. 2.2 Catalyst preparation All experimental steps were performed under anhydrous and oxygen-free conditions. All experimental drugs were stored in a glove box in an inert atmosphere in a glass bottle sealed with aluminum foil. Before synthesis, all reagents and solvents were purified by refluxing over Na under Ar for 12 h. Reagents and solvents were purged with inert gas. Molecular sieves were activated by heating under vacuum, then stored in an argon-filled glove box. The preparation of the POPs-supported metallocene catalysts was undertaken via a two-step method, incorporating MAO impregnation and Zirconcene impregnation. MAO impregnation: POP-OH-X (500 mg) was weighed into a 50 mL Schlenk tube. Toluene (5 mL) and methylaluminoxane (MAO, 10 wt% in toluene, 4 mL) were added slowly. The mixture was stirred gently at 110 ℃ for 3 h. The resulting product was collected by filtration, washed with toluene 2–3 times, and dried under vacuum to afford POP-X-MAO. Zirconocene impregnation: POP-X-MAO and a zirconocene compound were added sequentially to toluene with a POP-X-MAO-to-zirconocene mass ratio of 50: 1, and the mixture was gently stirred at room temperature for a period of 2 h. After filtration, the product was washed with toluene 2–3 times, and then vacuum-dried to afford the final product, denoted as CATPOP-X. 2.3 Polymerization Catalyst performance was evaluated by batch slurry polymerization. The reaction was performed under anhydrous and oxygen-free conditions. A 2 L autoclave reactor was heated to 120 °C and held under vacuum for 1 h. During heating, the system was purged with high-purity nitrogen (3–5 times) to remove residual water and oxygen. The temperature was then adjusted to the polymerization temperature. Hexane (1.2 L) and triisobutylaluminum (3 mL) were added sequentially. After stirring for 10 min, the catalyst was introduced. Ethylene feeding and rapid stirring commenced immediately. The ethylene flow was monitored in real time using flow meters. Polymerization was stopped when the instantaneous ethylene consumption rate fell below 0.4 L/min. The final polymer was dried in a fume hood for 24 h (denoted as CATPOP-X/PE). 2.4 Characterization The specific surface area, pore volume and average pore size of the samples were determined by adsorption of nitrogen at a low temperature (77.3 K) using a Specific Surface Area and Pore Size Analyzer (SSPAPA), model Mack Asap 2460 (USA). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation was used to calculate the specific surface area, and the t-plot method was used to calculate the pore volume. The pore size distribution (PSD) was obtained by calculation of the dV/dLogD pore volume from the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BJH) desorption method. The sample preparation stage was conducted within an argon glove box, with no preliminary treatment, before the execution of physiosorption measurements. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were measured using a PerkinElmer 2000 spectrometer, with 32 scans and a resolution of 4 cm−1. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were collected on a field emission scanning electron microscope (Merlin Compact). The TEM was determined using a JEOL JEM-F200 model from Japan, and the distribution of elements such as C, O, Al, and Zr in the samples was obtained by EDX energy spectroscopy surface scanning (Mapping) test. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) testing was conducted at ambient temperature using a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha, USA, with wide-scan spectra recorded in the 1351–0 eV binding energy range at a low resolution of 1 eV (100 eV through energy). High-resolution scans of Zr 3d3/2, Zr 3d5/2 and C1s were acquired at 0.05 eV resolution (by energy 20 eV). The Al and Zr contents of the samples were determined using inductively coupled plasma-emission spectrometry (Agilent 730 (OES), USA). The elemental distribution across the catalyst particle cross-section was obtained using focused ion beam (FIB) technology combined with scanning electron microscopy (SEM) + energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) (model: FEI Scios 2 HiVac, USA). A gallium ion beam (beam energy: 30 keV, current: 2 nA) was employed to cut the particles and produce a flat cross-section, which was subsequently analysed for Zr element distribution via SEM and EDS. The thermal stability of the catalyst samples was determined via thermogravimetric analysis (TA DISCOVERY 5500). The crystalline state of the catalyst samples was characterised using a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer (PXRD). The number average molecular weight (NAMW), weight average molecular weight (WAMW) and molecular weight distribution (MWD) of the polyethylene samples were determined by high temperature gel chromatography (GPC, PL-GPC-220, UK). The temperature and crystallinity of polyethylene were determined using a Universal V 2.3 C TA-type differential scanning calorimeter (DSC). Two continuous heating cycles and one cooling cycle were configured, with the temperature ranging from ambient temperature to 160℃ at a ramp rate of 10 ℃ /min. The enthalpy of melting of a 100 % crystallized polyethylene sample (293 J/g) was utilized as a reference to calculate the crystallinity of the samples. 3 Results and discussion We prepared porous organic polymers (POPs) with tunable specific surface area and pore volume, and with pore sizes suitable for metallocene immobilization. Subsequently, four POP carriers exhibiting differing chemical structures, specific surface areas, and pore architectures were selected based on these parameters and systematically investigated. The investigation focused on the four POPs and the materials after they underwent MAO loading and zirconocene loading. The objective of the loading process was to observe the effects of MAO and zirconium compound loading on the generation of active sites. The microstructure, chemistry and morphology of a series of POP-X-MAOs and their corresponding catalysts (CATPOP-X) were characterized by nitrogen physisorption, inductively coupled plasma-emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The investigation further encompassed the performance of various POPs-supported metallocene catalysts in the context of catalytic ethylene polymerization, alongside the properties of the resulting polyethylene (PE). The impact of surface chemical groups, specific surface area, pore volume and pore size of POPs as metallocene carriers on the impregnation and activation of MAO and zirconium metallocenes was analyzed to elucidate the disparate catalytic performances of these POPs-supported metallocene catalysts in the catalytic polymerization of ethylene. 3.1 Characterization of porous organic polymers Table S1 provides a detailed comparison of the specific surface area, the pore volume and the pore size of the POPs prepared under a range of different reaction conditions. As demonstrated in Table 1, entries 1–2, a larger specific surface area (SBET=298m2/g) and pore volume (0.23 cm3/g) were obtained when the amount of DCE was reduced. This is attributed to the fact that the reduction of DCE increased in the reaction exposure probability of phenol. A higher specific surface area (SBET = 355 m2/g) and pore volume (0.17 cm3/g) were obtained when the FDA and ferric chloride equivalents were reduced. This finding suggests that the FDA and ferric chloride (FeCl3) equivalents also have a significant effect on the pore properties of POPs. Reducing FDA and FeCl3 loading decreases the polymerization rate, thereby increasing the specific surface area and pore volume (Table 1, entry 3). Concurrently, the copolymer equivalents and types exerted substantial influence on the specific surface area and pore volume of POPs (entry 4 and entry 5). With increasing benzene equivalents of copolymer, a notable enhancement in the specific surface area was observed, ranging from 433 m2/g to 753 m2/g, along with a substantial augmentation in the pore volume from 0.22 cm3/g to 0.49 cm3/g. Surprisingly, the specific surface area and pore volume of the carriers obtained by polymerization with phenol and tetraphenylmethane under FDA and ferric chloride equivalents of 7 (Table 1, Entry 7) were found to be remarkably high, reaching 1407 m2/g and 1.04 cm3/g, respectively. Conversely, when aluminum chloride is utilized as a catalyst for the reaction, there is a substantial decrease in the specific surface area and pore volume of the carrier, even when all other conditions remain constant. This is attributable to the higher Lewis acidity of aluminum chloride in comparison to ferric chloride [40], which facilitates a more expeditious reaction. The results of the BET characterization of all POPs are demonstrated in Table S1 and Figure S1-9. The porosity of the four screened POPs was investigated by nitrogen adsorption measurements ( Fig. 2). The N₂ adsorption-desorption isotherms of POP-OH-2, POP-OH-5, POP-OH-6, and POP-OH-8 exhibited increased uptake at low relative pressures (P/P₀ < 0.1). At higher relative pressures, capillary coalescence was observed, indicating the presence of mesopores. To further ascertain the nature of the pore size distribution, the BJH desorption dV /dLogD pore volume measurement was employed. The results indicated that the pore size distribution of POP-OH-2 lay within the range of 10–60 nm, exhibiting a predominantly mesoporous structure, in conjunction with a limited presence of macropores. Furthermore, the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of other POPs also exhibited the typical behavior of mesoporous materials. The pore size distributions of both POP-OH-5 and POP-OH-6 exhibited two peaks: a minor peak at 2.94–3.8 nm and a major peak extending from 10 to 68 nm. The presence of these peaks demonstrates a hierarchical pore architecture containing micropores, mesopores, and macropores (Fig. 2b, c). The pore size of POP-OH-8 is mainly concentrated at 3.78 nm with a narrow pore size distribution (Fig. 2d), indicating the presence of exclusively mesopore structures with smaller pore sizes in POP-OH-8. It is noteworthy that the aromatic equivalents exerted a substantial influence on the N2 adsorption performance. Higher aromatic equivalent content in the monomers produced POPs exhibiting increased specific surface area and pore volume, alongside a significant shift in pore structure featuring a greater proportion of mesopores. 3.2 Catalyst characterization and the formation of active sites The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of the four POPs and their FTIR spectra before and after loading with MAO and zirconocene under vacuum conditions are presented in Fig. 3. Loading MAO and zirconocene altered the POPs' chemical structure, as evidenced by changes in characteristic infrared vibrational peaks. In POP-OH-2, Fig. 3a shows the hydroxyl group peak (3424 cm⁻¹, attributed to surface/defect sites), the aryl ring skeletal vibration (∼1614 cm⁻¹), and the C-O stretching vibration of phenol (∼1224 cm⁻¹). Similar peaks were also observed in POP-OH-5, POP-OH-6, and POP-OH-8; however, their intensity was slightly reduced due to the incorporation of the copolymer monomer. The vibrational signals of the phenol hydroxyl group in the POP-MAO loadings essentially disappeared, being replaced by C-H vibrational peaks in CH3 in the 2950–2930 cm−1 interval and Al-C bond vibrational peaks in the 690–650 cm−1 interval. Vibrational signals of the Al-C bond in MAO typically manifest at 700 cm−1 [41]. However, the reaction between MAO and the hydroxyl group on the surface of POPs caused a shift of the Al-C vibrational peaks towards lower wavenumbers. This shift indicates the successful grafting of MAO onto the POPs. Furthermore, the infrared spectra of zirconocene-loaded POPs, analogous to those of MAO-loaded POPs, exhibited no discernible new characteristic peaks. This absence of new peaks is likely attributable to the low zirconocene loading. To determine the zirconocene loading, elemental distribution analysis was performed using high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) coupled with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) ( Fig. 4). It can be intuitively deduced from Fig. 4, e-h, that the metallic elements in all CATPOP materials were uniformly dispersed in the POPs. And TEM analysis (Fig. 4a-d and Supporting Information) revealed that while the pore sizes of CATPOP-2, CATPOP-5, and CATPOP-6 were all significantly reduced after loading, CATPOP-2 and CATPOP-5 retained their mesoporous and partially macroporous morphology. In contrast, the pores of CATPOP-6 were very small. Consistent results were observed by SEM (Figure S30, Supporting Information). Conversely, when CATPOP-8 was prepared under the catalytic action of AlCl3, the resultant morphology was a dense bulk structure and lacked visible macropores (Figure S31, Supporting Information). Furthermore, XPS analysis showed that the Zr3d binding energies of homogeneous Cp2ZrCl2 were 181.78 and 184.15 eV, respectively. The binding energies of the CATPOP materials were found to be increased (Fig. 4, i-l), and this was attributed to the interaction between MAO and Cp2ZrCl2 to generate cationic active centers [42–45]. Notably, CATPOP-5 shows the largest binding energy increase (∼1.26 eV) compared to homogeneous Cp₂ZrCl₂, indicating a more electrophilic character (i.e., greater cationic tendency) in this system. Furthermore, the binding energy shifts for CATPOP-6 (0.94 eV), CATPOP-2 (0.82 eV), and CATPOP-8 (0.72 eV) vary significantly, reflecting their distinct electrophilic properties. Further elemental analyses were conducted before and after loading of POPs with MAO and Zr metallocene, as obtained by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). The results of BET tests are presented in Table 2. The results confirmed successful loading of both MAO and Zr metallocene onto the POPs, with loading efficiencies varying according to Al and Zr contents. Specifically, the Al contents were determined to be 17.51 % for POP-2-MAO, 18.00 % for POP-5-MAO, 20.25 % for POP-6-MAO, and 15.71 % for POP-8-MAO. The relative decrease in Al content following the loading of Zr metallocene was found to be 16.51 %, 18.21 %, 19.63 % and 16.98 %, respectively. Concurrently, the Zr content decreased by 0.44 %, 0.42 %, 0.40 % and 0.31 %, while the Al/Zr ratio increased to 126.87, 146.60, 165.93 and 185.24, respectively. These findings suggest that the four POPs for Al and Zr exhibited substantial variations in loading efficiency. The BET results showed a substantial decline in SBET and pore capacity of POP-OH-5, 6 and 8, following loading with MAO and Zr metallocene. This phenomenon can be attributed to the presence of MAO and Zr metallocenes occupying a portion of the pore channel during the loading process. Specifically, the SBET of POP-OH-2 increased from 298 m2/g to 333 m2/g after loading MAO, while the pore volume continued to decrease. The pore parameters of these POPs loaded with MAO and Zr metallocene provide a plausible explanation for the differences in the final aluminum-zirconium loading efficiencies obtained. POP-2-MAO and CATPOP-2 exhibited higher aluminum-zirconium loading efficiencies (21.3 % and 21.7 %, respectively) and increasing then decreasing specific surface areas (333 m²/g and 289 m²/g, respectively). This is attributable to the large pore size of POP-OH-2, which facilitated easier access to the methylaluminoxane and zirconocene compounds. For POP-OH-5 and POP-OH-6, the copolymer monomer incorporation increased the mesoporous structure percentage, leading to moderately reduced Al-Zr loading efficiencies while maintaining substantial specific surface areas (663, 539, 438, and 336 m²/g for POP-5-MAO, POP-6-MAO, CATPOP-5, and CATPOP-6, respectively). In contrast, POP-8-MAO and CATPOP-8 exhibited significantly lower surface areas (238 and 49 m²/g), which we attribute to their narrow pore size (19.1–21.7 Å). This dimension approaches the size range of MAO clusters (19 Å, under reflux conditions [46]), likely restricting internal diffusion and resulting in predominant surface grafting of both MAO and zirconocene species. To elucidate the MAO/zirconocene loading mechanisms, we analyzed pore size distributions derived from BJH desorption calculations ( Fig. 5). Comparative analysis revealed distinct pore size shifts in POP-OH-2, 5, 6, and 8 after MAO/zirconocene loading. Notably, pore width reduction post-loading (most pronounced in POP-OH-2) confirms predominant MAO grafting within internal pores. POP-OH-5 displayed a significant mesopore proportion increase after loading, while POP-OH-6 showed obvious pore size variation, consistent with its high MAO loading efficiency (44.91 %) (Supporting Information, Table S2). The aluminium loading efficiency of POP-OH-8 (43.08 %) is marginally lower than that of POP-OH-6 (44.91 %), with the loading MAO pore size distribution virtually disappearing. This finding suggests that the internal channels of POP-OH-8 have been entirely occupied by MAO molecules. Subsequent zirconocene loading further reduced CATPOP pore widths, with CATPOP-6 demonstrating the most dramatic decrease to ∼3.55 nm, likely due to its MAO's superior zirconocene-binding capacity. CATPOP-8 showed virtually no detectable porosity, yet achieved 14.48 % Zr loading efficiency, indicating predominant surface grafting (Supporting Information, Table S2). The distribution of aluminium (Al) and zirconium (Zr) across the catalyst cross-section provides a visual representation of the corresponding methylaluminoxane (MAO) and zirconocene active site dispersion. As shown in Fig. 6, the intensity of yellow and purple signals corresponds to the relative concentrations of Al and Zr, respectively. Al is uniformly distributed at high concentration throughout the internal pores of all CATPOP materials. In contrast, while Zr is detectable across the catalyst interior, its distribution varies considerably among samples: in CATPOP-2, Zr is homogeneously dispersed; in CATPOP-5, it is concentrated in the core region; and in CATPOP-6 and CATPOP-8, Zr is predominantly localised near the external surface. These observations are consistent with our previous findings: both POP-OH-2 and POP-OH-5 maintain broad pore size distributions after MAO treatment, facilitating diffusion and homogeneous incorporation of metallocene complexes throughout the catalyst particles. In contrast, POP-OH-6 and POP-OH-8 exhibit pore narrowing or blockage following MAO immersion, which restricts metallocene loading predominantly to the outer regions. In conclusion, the successful loading of methylaluminoxane (MAO) and zirconocene metallocene into POP-OH-2, POP-OH-5, POP-OH-6, and POP-OH-8 with different degrees of intensity has been confirmed by the Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR), the results of elemental analyses, and the porosity tests. Importantly, the loading process of MAO and zirconocene resulted in only a modification of the internal pore structure of the carriers, with no detrimental effects observed on the carriers themselves, including their morphology and microstructure. 3.3 Ethylene polymerization performance and related polyethylene properties The catalytic ethylene polymerization performance of POPs-supported metallocene catalysts is summarized in Table S3 (Supporting Information). The results of the evaluation of catalytic activity showed that all POPs-supported metallocene catalysts exhibited excellent ethylene polymerization activity. Among the tested samples, CATPOP-5 exhibited the optimal performance, with a high activity of 20513 kg PE (mol Zr)−1h−1. This was followed by CATPOP-6 (17637 kg PE (mol Zr)−1h−1), CATPOP-8 (12493 kg PE (mol Zr)−1h−1), and CATPOP-2 (11811 kg PE (mol Zr)−1h−1) ( Fig. 7c). The high activity of the material may be attributed to two factors. Firstly, the material has a high specific surface area and large pore volume. Catalysts featuring high specific surface area and macroporosity enhance the dispersion of active sites, ethylene adsorption, and polymerization activity. Supports with such textural properties facilitate the incorporation of active centers within the pore network and on the external surface, enabling superior loadings. For instance, CATPOP-5 supported a maximum aluminium loading of 20.25 % with a zirconium content above 0.4 %. In contrast, microporous POPs with narrow pore diameters predominantly confine active sites to the external surface, resulting in diminished Al and Zr loadings (15.71 % and 0.31 %, respectively). A uniform distribution of active sites throughout the catalyst matrix is advantageous, as their progressive exposure during polymerization-induced fragmentation sustains chain propagation over extended durations, thereby promoting catalyst longevity. Secondly, its electrophilic properties are the strongest of the four catalyst materials (Fig. 4j, XPS results analysis). In the context of metallocene-catalyzed olefin polymerization, the H on the α-C of the growing chain typically undergoes an electron-donating effect on the transition metal cation (α-agostic effect [47,48]). Indeed, the electron-donating effect in ethylene polymerization is known as the 'electron cloud migration process'. The formation of the cationic active center (Cp2ZrCH3 +) transforms the zirconium atom into a strongly electrophilic central atom with holes [49], thereby enabling the π-electron cloud of the ethylene molecule to be readily superimposed on it. The α-agostic effect has been found to lead to a reduction in the transition state energy of the monomer insertion growth process, thus allowing chain growth to proceed smoothly. This is the reason for the extremely high catalytic activity of metallocene catalysts. Consequently, the high activity of CATPOP-5 is most likely attributable to its strong electrophilic property from the micro-mechanistic perspective. Furthermore, the divergent activities exhibited by CATPOP-2, CATPOP-6, and CATPOP-8 could be attributable to the distinct pore structures and microchemical mechanisms inherent in these materials. On the one hand, the loading of MAO and zirconium metallocene resulted in a substantial decrease in the specific surface area, the pore volume and the pore size of the POPs. This led to a limitation of the diffusion of ethylene molecules within the catalysts. Conversely, the divergent monomer structures could also be a contributing factor. The moderate activity of CATPOP-6 and CATPOP-8 can be ascribed to the fact that a substantial number of π-electron clouds in the benzene ring structure of the copolymer monomers overlap with zirconium holes. This hinders the migration of the electron clouds of the ethylene molecules to the cationic active center. The lower activity exhibited by CATPOP-2 may be ascribed to the capacity of the hydroxyl groups present on the linker molecules to function as Bronsted acid sites [50,51]. These groups are capable of interacting with the zirconium metallocenes [52], thereby leading to a reduction and subsequent degradation of the active metallocene catalyst structure, resulting in a decrease in catalytic activity. In addition, the polymerization kinetics of CATPOPs were investigated by real-time variation of ethylene flow rate during ethylene polymerization (Fig. 7a). The results showed that the POPs-supported metallocene catalysts had almost no initiation period during the polymerization process, and the initial activities all increased rapidly. The highest equilibrium point of ethylene transient flux was reached for all four catalysts (CATPOP-2 (1.26 L/min), CATPOP-5 (2.37 L/min), CATPOP-6 (2.3 L/min), and CATPOP-8 (0.95 L/min)) within 0–10 min, and then the activity slowly decayed in the release. However, the polymerization kinetics of the four catalysts exhibited differential behavior. The catalytic lifetimes of CATPOP-5 and CATPOP-6 exceeded 2 h, and the highest equilibrium points of ethylene transient fluxes and overall kinetic profiles were attained at levels greater than those of CATPOP-2 and CATPOP-8. We attribute this enhanced performance to their superior textural properties - including higher surface areas, larger pore volumes, and well-developed mesoporosity - which facilitate ethylene diffusion and active site accessibility. In contrast, the catalytic lifetimes of CTAPOP-2 and CATPOP-8 were shorter (both <2 h). Kinetic analysis revealed that CATPOP-2 exhibited higher initial activity than CATPOP-8 during the rapid activation phase, whereas CATPOP-8 demonstrated superior activity retention during the prolonged decay period. The explanation for this phenomenon is that CATPOP-2 possesses a more substantial pore structure in comparison to CATPOP-8. Nevertheless, the loss of active centers precipitates the swift decline of its activity. The kinetics of CATPOP-8, exhibiting low levels and accelerated decay, further corroborate the hypothesis that its zirconium active centers are predominantly concentrated on the surface of the carrier. Consequently, the loading efficiency of CATPOP-8 zirconium metallocene is comparatively low (Al/Zr molar ratios up to 185). Furthermore, while CATPOP-2, CATPOP-5, CATPOP-6 and CATPOP-8 exhibited disparate loading efficiencies (Fig. 7c,d) and the Al/Zr molar ratios underwent a gradual increase, their ethylene polymerization activities demonstrated an alternating pattern of increasing and decreasing trends. It is suggested that an Al/Zr molar ratio within the range of 146–165 may be more conducive to the effective functioning of the active center. Concurrently, the observed polymerization kinetics and enhanced ethylene polymerization activity of the POP-supported metallocene catalysts indicate effective catalyst fragmentation, enabling sustained ethylene access to zirconium active sites within the growing oligomer matrix. This interpretation is further supported by SEM characterization. Fig. 8 displays the surface morphology of all four CATPOPs/PE, showing that a “ribbon structure [53]” is manifested on the surface of all four PEs, attributable to the interaction of ethylene molecules with the active sites on the catalyst's surface. During the polymerization process, these ethylene molecules initially grew into oligomer chains. Concurrently, the adsorption and fragmentation of the catalyst resulted in the contact of these ethylene molecules with new active sites, leading to further growth and expansion. A substantial number of irregularities were identified on the surfaces of CATPOP-2/PE, CATPOP-5/PE, and CATPOP-6/PE. It was observed that PE exhibited a substantial quantity of irregular, spherical-like PE particles on their surfaces (Fig. 8, a-c). This finding indicates that CATPOP-2, CATPOP-5, and CATPOP-6 underwent significant fragmentation during the polymerization process, suggesting that ethylene molecules continued to grow. In contrast, the surface of CATPOP-8/PE exhibited a significantly rougher texture, and the drawing phenomenon was less pronounced in CATPOP-6/PE and CATPOP-8/PE (Fig. 8, c-d). This observation provides additional evidence that the internal pores of CATPOP-6 and CATPOP-8 were insufficiently robust to permit the efficient entry of ethylene molecules. To characterize the polyethylene (PE) products from different CATPOP catalysts, we analyzed their molecular weight and thermal properties. GPC results ( Table 3) revealed weight-average molecular weights (Mw) of 2.75 × 104 (CATPOP-2/PE), 2.62 × 104 (CATPOP-5/PE), 2.62 × 104 (CATPOP-6/PE), and 2.91 × 104 g/mol (CATPOP-8/PE). Fig. 6b provides a visual representation of the GPC curves for the four catalyst materials utilized in the preparation of PE, accompanied by the molecular weight distributions (MWDs) and polydispersity indices (PDIs) of 2.6 (CATPOP-2/PE), 3.0 (CATPOP-5/PE), 2.3 (CATPOP-6/PE), and 2.6 (CATPOP-8/PE), respectively. Furthermore, the melting temperature (Tm), the crystallization temperature (Tc), and the corresponding enthalpy of melting (ΔHf) of the four CATPOP/PEs were determined, and the degree of crystallinity, %Xd, was calculated. DSC analysis showed melting temperatures (Tm) of 135°C for CATPOP-2/PE, 5/PE, and 6/PE, and 136°C for CATPOP-8/PE, with crystallinity (%Xd) ranging 50–88 %. These values are characteristic of high-density polyethylene (HDPE), indicating similar chain packing densities despite molecular weight variations. 4 Conclusions In this study, we successfully prepared porous organic polymers (POPs) with tunable chemical and pore structures by the direct knitting method and used them as carriers for ethylene polymerization loaded with Cp2ZrCl2. The characterization data demonstrate the broad tunability of these POPs' textural properties, with specific surface areas (158–1407 m2/g) and pore volumes (0.15–1.04 cm3/g) spanning nearly. The POPs-supported metallocene catalysts demonstrated commendable stability and excellent catalytic activity in ethylene polymerization. Notably, these catalysts exhibited no initiation period for the catalytic ethylene polymerization process. The enhanced cumulative catalytic activity (5.1 ×104 kgPE(mol Zr)−1) was achieved when the catalyst specific surface area was 438 m2/g and the pore volume was 0.26 cm3/g. Furthermore, Systematic characterization revealed that both surface functional groups and porous architecture of POPs critically determine (i) metallocene active site distribution during immobilization and (ii) resultant ethylene polymerization performance. The distribution of zirconium active centers and high catalytic activity was facilitated by appropriate pore structure and the presence of hydroxyl groups. Consequently, it is hypothesized that the diversity and tunability of the chemical and pore structure of POPs will provide a broad prospect for the development of new efficient olefin polymerization catalysts and high-performance polyolefin materials. coredata.dc:description: Immobilizing metallocene catalysts on suitable carriers can overcome the drawbacks of their homogeneous counterpart in catalyzing olefin polymerization. However, the development of porous organic carriers with tunable specific surface area, pore structure and commendable compatibility for metallocene catalyst loading remains challenging. In this study, porous organic polymers (POPs) with tunable specific surface area (158–1407 m2/g) and pore volume (0.15–1.04 cm3/g) were successfully fabricated by a facile one-pot method through direct knitting of aromatic copolymer monomers. We provided a comprehensive investigation into the impact of specific surface area, pore structure and chemical structure of POPs on the catalytic polymerization of ethylene as POPs-supported metallocene catalysts. The results reveal that interactions among POPs, MAO and Cp2ZrCl2 govern both the formation and spatial distribution of active sites as well as the overall catalytic activity. The catalytic kinetics show that the POPs-supported metallocene catalysts exhibited no initiation period during ethylene polymerization. And the catalytic activity (20513 kgPE(mol Zr)−1h−1) is reached with a support possessing a specific surface area of 438 m2/g and a pore volume of 0.26 cm3/g. This work highlights the significant potential of POPs as tailor-made porous organic polymer carriers for metallocene-catalyzed ethylene polymerization.
coredata.dc:title: Tailored pores, enhanced activity: Porous organic polymer-supported metallocene catalysts for ethylene polymerization
